Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The shrill whistle was still echoing in my ears as I spotted the group of teenagers, laughing and shoving each other dangerously close to the pool’s edge, right beneath the bold red “NO DIVING” sign. As a lifeguard, I knew I had to act—enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, even if it meant being the bad guy. But before I could move, the building’s alarms blared, and my phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning. Through the glass, I saw water creeping up the street, swirling around parked cars. As a citizen, I was supposed to help—evacuate, alert neighbors, maybe even check on the elderly couple next door. My heart pounded. Should I rush outside to help my community, or stay and confront the reckless teens, risking their safety if I left? Both roles demanded my full attention, but I couldn’t be in two places at once. The weight of responsibility pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, torn between the pool and the rising floodwaters, knowing I had to choose.
